I’m not gonna say that these are all useless or futile ideas; they’re not, they are obviously very useful material properties and very interesting for many reasons. But to say that they could be used in structures as they currently are is very misleading and it really make this channel seem more like click bait science than actual science.

Just as an example with your first example: how happens with the weight of water in the building material? Is there enough water released to actually cool a fire to extinguishment? How does the water reach all the fire sources when the material is behind walls/flooring/ceilings? How do we compensate for the change of weight of the material when it releases the water? How do the stresses change on a buildings structure when the weights change? Will the building foundation survive the extreme change in forces after the weight change? How will we replenish the water in the material after it’s used? Will that cause more problems?

Science is amazing, but click bait like this is trash. Scientific answers need to be had before we can start talking about applications of those scientific achievements. Be better, Hank. It’s sad to see you doing this sh!t video after video when I know you’re better than that

So once again we see how design already existing in nature is far beyond what humans have been doing. It provides a guideline we can strive to emulate. And yet, few ever contemplate or appreciate the source of such masterful design. Seldom is asked the question, "How likely is it that natural selection of random point mutations could actually cause such magnificent, sublime, clever and beautiful design?"

Besides the fine qualities mentioned in this video, contemplate metamorphosis of a caterpillar into a butterfly. How could random point mutations ever cause that ability to begin to exist? There are thousands of radical steps needed to transform into an entirely different type of creature. One cannot write the code for this piecemeal. An incomplete metamorphosis is not going to result in a creature more suited to survival than a caterpillar or likely any sort of functional creature at all. It is all or nothing and that is too much for the gradualism evolutionary theory uses as an excuse for the unlikelihood of what it is claims to accomplish.

Then of course how could natural selection of random point mutations result in crucial instinctive knowledge? Within a minute a newly emerge butterfly knows it can fly and how to do it, where to find and how to eat nectar (an entirely different type of food than it has ever know before), how to successfully gain a mate and where to migrate to thousands of miles away. So many vital abilities and knowledge it has to have without learning or being taught.

All this knowledge and the wonderful design found everywhere, which we do well to seek to learn from, are far beyond what accidental genetic mistakes could ever produce. Often too much change and new knowledge must be gained upon the instant of a radical transition for natural selection of mistakes to ever be plausibly be given credit for. For example, it is presumed land animals became marine mammals such as dolphins and whales. These must sleep with half their brain at a time so that the other half can keep swimming and surfacing to breathe. That's something you have to get 100% correct from day one or you will drown. Those are abilities totally unneeded until the instant you use them for the first time and then they must be completely functional. That is not how evolution is supposed to work. One doesn't save up a vast set of changes in case a descendant might one day radically change its lifestyle. Let's say all these required changes were finally complete. How do you know you can now sleep in the water with half your brain still swimming? I'll bet you've never tried it just in case you could. Why would any creature? You would have to also lose all the instinctive reactions which normally prevent this.

Anyway, I love the wonderful science and design everywhere and always get a bit bugged when no credit it given to the Great Designer all of this points to. Design requires a Designer. Information requires a Source. Credit keeps being given to natural selection of random mutations when that is not really a functional method of gaining completely new abilities, instinctive knowledge and other radical transformations. I'm not into being ungrateful. Give credit where credit is due.

(Revelation 4:11) “You are worthy, Jehovah our God, to receive the glory and the honor and the power, because you created all things, and because of your will they came into existence and were created.”

Those to whom the idea of an intelligent, capable designer is anathema, even though that is the only workable explanation, will likely heap insults rather than answer the questions raised or honestly contemplate the limits of what natural selection of random mutations could actually result in. Let's see if responses are petty or honest.

As Harvard evolutionary geneticist Richard Lewontin confessed,
"It is not that the methods and institutions of science somehow compel us to accept a material explanation of the phenomenal world but, on the contrary, that we are forced by our a prioiri adherence to material causes to create an apparatus of investigation and a set of concepts that produce material explanations, no matter how counter-intuitive, no matter how mystifying to the uninitiated. Moreover, that materialism is absolute for we cannot allow a divine foot in the door."

Here are numerous further examples of the wonderful capabilities of nature and asks the natural question "Was it Designed?"

Gone are the days when biologists were looked down on as studying the easy science. With the growth of molecular biology in some 70 years ago we see the shift in medicine follow to treat the body with greater understanding of the physiologic pathways. Decades ago Janine Benyus began teaching engineers the benefits of biomimicry. She described how to go beyond a point where technology had reached a design limitation. Her lectures focused on where to seek the answer in nature, nature that had 3.8 billion years to field test the concepts in evolving ecosystems.

She pointed out the kinds of possible questions to ask. How do living organisms adapt to prevent mineral scaling build up in their structure as marine organisms? How does nature adapt to minimize energy? How to make room temperature ceramics without high temperature kilns like abalone shells and diatoms shells? How to adhere to slick surfaces without adhesives likes geckoes or spiders? How to shed dirt with rain drops like lotus plant leaves? How to redesign ecosystems without fatal disruptions by the use of water like beaver dams?
http://www.ted.com/index.php/talks/janine_benyus_shares_nature_s_designs.html
http://www.biomimicryinstitute.org/
http://www.asknature.org/

Self dimming windows already have existed for decades, although using another method and design. But the concept itself isn't new.

The polymer shifting is an interesting thought, but I have a slightly better idea. How about instead of expensive silver polymers, we instead use photochromic dye films? You might know them better as Transition lenses, and as they respond specifically to direct and semi-direct UV light, they would have the added benefit of not applying a heat conductive metallic silver material to a window in a hot environment, while also keeping windows fully see-through, just shaded. They would also have the benefit of not significantly reducing your light levels when you're dealing with a shaded window. The hazard of this, and of the polymer coating as well, is that in both cases, you're reducing your incoming light level, which increases the need for relying on electric light, which generates more heat IN the home, to say nothing of the increases in CO2 emissions due to the increased wear on the power grid.

I wonder if the concrete products are made with the normal type of concrete with stone aggregate or the more temperature resistant light-weight concrete developed about 30 years ago using small polymer beads instead of the stone. Replacing the stone with polymer reduces the weight a lot, and because the beads can compress or expand a little it greatly reduces cracking in the concrete. While I've seen projects made with it, I've need seen it in widespread use in the building industry.

I'm an Artist (& Biology student), and so see Biomimicry from perhaps a slightly different perspective than, say, an engineer. That said, I've seen a truly extraordinary number of applications of biologically derived design concepts / engineering over the past few years, and the rate of wondrous new Biomimicry developments seems only to be increasing.

• The darkest black paints in existence (Black 3.0 boasts over 99.98% visible light absorption) use carbon nanotube "mazes" to capture incoming photons, working exactly the same as the feathers of some bird wings & the integument of some deep sea fish.
• Some new colour pigments even rely on nanoscale surface structures, rather than the light absorption/reflection capability of the material, to create the particular hue - functioning in exactly the same way as the scales on a butterflies wings do.
• Manufacturers have designed the internal reinforcing structures of objects as varied as cars, shoes & chairs, using the fibrous lattice structure of the interiors of human/bird bones - optimising the ratio of strength to mass to a remarkable degree.
• Civil Engineers are planning the road layouts of future cities (& other infrastructure, such as power/data/water/sewer
conduits) based on the extremely efficient growth patterns of slime moulds & the adaptive flow dynamics of the human circulatory system.
• High-rise buildings have been built with highly energy efficient internal environment controls (heating/cooling) based on the passive structures of termite mounds - tremendously reducing both the running costs & environmental impact of old fashioned air conditioning systems.
• Super quiet fan blades designed using the micro-vortice inducing characteristics of an owl's wings/feathers.
• Water repellent materials/coatings based on the Superhydrophobic surface of the Lotus leaf. Inversely, a varient of this technology may be used to attract oils, potentially creating capture nets for oil spills.
And so, so many more...

Along with profound advancements in Nanotechnology & Computer / AI Designs, Biomimicry is moving humanity towards an unparalleled new age of development.

There are quite a few developments for passive heating systems, including GAHT, water tanks and solar focusing, and in the right environment organisms themselves are a sufficient heat source (example: winter aquaponics).

Our company Arctic Acres manufactures geodesic growing dome greenhouses, alongside an expanding list of features that make them ideal for 365 home growing. We want to create the greenhouse of the future that can be a sustainable solution to growing concerns.

Our domes current operate in Nunavut Canada to help sustain entire remote communities, they can withstand 180km/hr winds (that’s a category 2 hurricane), they are 2/3rds more energy efficient than conventional designs, can take 250lbs/sqft of snow load, and look absolutely beautiful.
